_header: Your eyen two will slay me suddenly
_description: Geoffrey Chaucer, ‘Merciles Beaute’ — a triple roundel, thirty-nine lines

CamMagPep2006.First Lines:
Yowr two yen woll sle me sodenlyI may the beaute of them not
                    susteneSo wondeth it þorow out my herte keneAnd but your word
                    woll helen hastelyMi hertis wound while that it is greneSyn I fro loue
                    escaped am so fat…
CamMagPep2006.Last Lines:
…I neuer thenk to ben in his prisoun leneSyn I am fre I counte
                    hym not a bene

BLAdd38179.First Lines:
Your two yen wille sle me sodenlyI may þe beaute of them not
                    sustene…
BLAdd38179.Last Lines:
…And he is strike out of my bokes cleneFor euer mo this is non
                    othir mene
BLAdd38179.Note:
MS source unknown; seventeenth-century transcript by Ainsworth is London,  British Library Addit. 38179, Part II, f. 5; apparently derived from Cambridge UK,  Magdalene College Pepys 2006 or its source. Two lines are added in a different hand
                    from rest of text.
